active_learning.discussion_prompt: In a group discussion, debate the trade-offs of implementing RBAC versus ABAC in a cloud database environment (e.g., Azure AD). Consider scalability, management overhead, and security in dynamic teams. Support arguments with real-world examples like hospital patient records access.

active_learning.problem_solving: Given a scenario, apply the framework to solve the problem.

layer.name: Layer 1
layer.content: Define RBAC as a method restricting access based on roles. Key terms: Users (subjects like employees/devices), Roles (job function groups), Permissions (actions on resources: view/create/modify/delete), Sessions (active role instances). Core rules: 1) Role Assignment (user to role); 2) Role Authorization (permitted roles); 3) Role Activation (user activates roles in session). Textual concept map: Central: RBAC → Users → Roles → Permissions; Branches: Sessions (activation); Dependencies: Assignment → Activation → Permission Exercise.

layer.name: Layer 2
layer.content: RBAC models: Core (basic flat structure), Hierarchical (inheritance: junior roles inherit senior), Constrained (SoD: mutual exclusion, e.g., can't assign conflicting roles like Approver and Executor). Relations: Permissions grouped into roles; users assigned multiple roles but activate subset per session. Diagram description: Users |→ Roles (many-to-many) |→ Permissions (many-to-many).

layer.name: Layer 3
layer.content: Step-by-step: 1) Identify job functions → Define roles (e.g., Doctor: view/modify records); 2) Assign permissions to roles; 3) Assign users to roles; 4) Activate via sessions; 5) Database example (SQL): CREATE ROLE doctor; GRANT SELECT, UPDATE ON patient_records TO doctor; GRANT doctor TO user_john. Real-world: Hospital - Nurse role: read-only records, no delete.

layer.name: Layer 4
layer.content: Integrate with ABAC (hybrid), cloud (Azure AD scopes), authentication. Benefits: Simplifies management, enforces least privilege. Pitfalls/Misconceptions: Role explosion (too many roles), ignoring reviews. Best practices: Periodic audits, SoD enforcement, constrained RBAC for compliance (e.g., GDPR in databases).
